title: Practice Challenge
description:
Create a generic function and interface:

1. Create a generic function `wrapInArray<T>` that:
   - Takes a single value of type T
   - Returns an array containing just that value: [value]

2. Create a generic interface `Result<T>` with:
   - `success`: boolean
   - `data`: T (the generic type)
   - `error`: string | null

3. Create a function `createSuccess<T>` that:
   - Takes a data parameter of type T
   - Returns a Result<T> with success: true, the data, and error: null

4. Test with different types (string, number, object)
instructions:
Create a generic function and interface:

1. Create a generic function `wrapInArray<T>` that:
   - Takes a single value of type T
   - Returns an array containing just that value: [value]

2. Create a generic interface `Result<T>` with:
   - `success`: boolean
   - `data`: T (the generic type)
   - `error`: string | null

3. Create a function `createSuccess<T>` that:
   - Takes a data parameter of type T
   - Returns a Result<T> with success: true, the data, and error: null

4. Test with different types (string, number, object)

testCases.description: wrapInArray should wrap value in array

hints.text: For wrapInArray, add <T> after the function name, then use T for the parameter type and T[] for the return type.
For the Result interface, add <T> after the interface name: interface Result<T>. Then use T for the data property type.

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting to add <T> to the function or interface
commonMistakes.consequence: TypeScript won't recognize it as a generic type.
commonMistakes.correction: Add <T> immediately after the function/interface name: function name<T>(...) or interface Name<T> {...}

commonMistakes.mistake: Using 'any' instead of the generic type parameter
commonMistakes.consequence: Loses type safety - the whole point of generics.
commonMistakes.correction: Replace 'any' with 'T' (or your type parameter name) to maintain type relationships.

commonMistakes.consequence: While TypeScript can infer, explicit types make code clearer.
commonMistakes.correction: Add return type: function wrapInArray<T>(value: T): T[] { ... }
